001package imagingbook.lib.util;
002
003import java.io.File;
004import java.io.IOException;
005import java.io.InputStream;
006import java.net.URI;
007import java.net.URISyntaxException;
008import java.net.URL;
009import java.nio.file.FileSystem;
010import java.nio.file.FileSystemNotFoundException;
011import java.nio.file.FileSystems;
012import java.nio.file.Files;
013import java.nio.file.Path;
014import java.nio.file.Paths;
015import java.util.ArrayList;
016import java.util.Arrays;
017import java.util.Collections;
018import java.util.Iterator;
019import java.util.List;
020import java.util.stream.Stream;
021
022/**
023 * Any resource directory is supposed to contain a class extending
024 * this class (the class name is arbitrary). 
025 * This is to make sure that every resource directory
026 * is also a Java package known to exist at compile time.
027 * For example, in file {@code imagingbook.data.images.Resources.java}:
028 * <pre>
029 * package imagingbook.data.images;
030 * public class Resources extends ResourceLocation { }
031 * </pre>
032 * All resources are assumed to be local in the SAME directory ONLY,
033 * thereby avoiding the use of strings to specify sub-directories.
034 * Example how to access the associated resources from some other class:
035 * <pre>
036 * ResourceLocation rd = new imagingbook.data.images.Resources();
037 * Path path = rd.getResourcePath("boats.tif");
038 * </pre>
039 * Specifically, an image can be opened as follows:
040 * <pre>
041 * Path path = rd.getResourcePath("boats.tif");
042 * ImagePlus im = IjUtils.openImage(path);
043 * ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
044 * ...
045 * </pre>
046 * Note that under the canonical Maven project structure, the associated file 
047 * locations (package structure) are:
048 * <pre>
049 * src/main/java/imagingbook/data/images/Resources.java (the marker class extending {@link ResourceLocation})
050 * src/main/resources/imagingbook/data/images/boats.tif ... (the actual resource files)
051 * </pre>
052 * or (if resources are used for testing only)
053 * <pre>
054 * src/test/java/imagingbook/data/images/Resources.java (the marker class extending {@link ResourceLocation})
055 * src/test/resources/imagingbook/data/images/boats.tif ... (the actual resource files)
056 * </pre>
057 * 
058 * @author WB
059 * @version 2020/11/22
060 */
061public abstract class ResourceLocation {
062        
063        private final Class<? extends ResourceLocation> clazz;
064        
065        protected ResourceLocation() {
066                this.clazz = this.getClass();
067        }
068
069        /**
070         * Determines if this class was loaded from
071         * a JAR file or from the file system.
072         * 
073         * @return true if contained in a JAR file, false otherwise
074         */
075        public boolean isInsideJAR() {
076                URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
077                String path = url.getPath();
078                File file = new File(path);
079                return file.isFile();
080        }
081        
082        /**
083         * Returns the path to the file location of this class.
084         * @return The path to this class.
085         */
086        public Path getResourcePath() {
087                return getResourcePath("");
088        }
089        
090        /**
091         * Returns the path to a resource relative to the location of this class.
092         *  
093         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including file extension)
094         * @return The path to the specified resource or {@code null} if not found
095         */
096        public Path getResourcePath(String resourceName) {
097                URI uri = getURI(resourceName);
098                return (uri == null) ? null : uriToPath(uri);
099        }
100        
101        /**
102         * Returns the specified resource as an {@link InputStream}.
103         * This is essentially a wrapper to {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
104         * 
105         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including file extension)
106         * @return A stream or {@code null} if the resource is not found.
107         */
108        public InputStream getResourceAsStream(String resourceName) {
109                return clazz.getResourceAsStream(resourceName);
110        }
111        
112        /**
113         * Returns the simple names of all resources within this class's directory
114         * (excluding the class file itself).
115         * This should work in an ordinary file system as well as a (possibly nested) 
116         * JAR file.
117         * 
118         * @return A sorted array of names (possibly empty)
119         */
120        public String[] getResourceNames() {
121                final String className = clazz.getSimpleName();
122                Path[] paths = getResourcePaths(getResourcePath(""));
123                List<String> nameList = new ArrayList<>(paths.length);
124                for (Path p : paths) {
125                        String name = p.getFileName().toString();
126                        // exclude .java and .class files of THIS class
127                        String nameOnly = FileUtils.stripFileExtension(name);
128                        if (!nameOnly.equals(className)) {
129                                nameList.add(name);
130                        }
131                }
132                String[] sa = nameList.toArray(new String[0]);
133                Arrays.sort(sa);
134                return sa;
135        }
136        
137        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
138        
139        /**
140         * Finds the URI for a resource relative to (in the directory/package of) this class.
141         * The resource may be located in the file system or inside a JAR file.
142         * 
143         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including file extension)
144         * @return The URI or {@code null} if the resource was not found
145         */
146        private URI getURI(String resourceName) {
147                URI uri = null;
148                if (isInsideJAR()) {
149                        String classPath = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
150                        //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
151                        String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
152                        String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + resourceName;
153                        try {
154                                uri = new URI(compPath);
155                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
156                                // throw new RuntimeException("getResourceURI: " + e.toString());
157                        }       
158                }
159                else {  // regular file path
160                        try {
161                                URL url = clazz.getResource(resourceName);
162                                if (url != null) {
163                                        uri = url.toURI();
164                                }
165                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
166                                //do nothing, just return null
167                        }
168                }
169                return uri;
170        }
171        
172        /**
173         * Converts an URI to a Path for locations that are either
174         * in the file system or inside a JAR file.
175         * 
176         * @param uri The specified location (URI)
177         * @return The associated path
178         */
179        private static Path uriToPath(URI uri) {
180                Path path = null;
181                String scheme = uri.getScheme();
182                switch (scheme) {
183                case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
184                        FileSystem fs = null;
185                        try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
186                                fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
187                        } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
188                                // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
189                        }
190                        
191                        if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
192                                try {
193                                        fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
194                                } catch (IOException e) {
195                                        throw new RuntimeException("uriToPath: " + e.toString());
196                                }
197                        }
198                        
199                        String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
200                        int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
201                        String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
202                        path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
203                        break;
204                }
205                case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
206                        path = Paths.get(uri);
207                        break;
208                }
209                default:
210                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
211                }
212                return path;
213        }
214        
215        /**
216         * Returns the paths to all files in a directory specified
217         * by a path. This should work in an ordinary file system
218         * as well as a (possibly nested) JAR file.
219         * 
220         * @param path The path to a directory (may be contained in a JAR file) 
221         * @return An array of paths or {@code null} if the specified path 
222         * is not a directory
223         */
224        private static Path[] getResourcePaths(Path path) {
225                // with help from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1429172/how-do-i-list-the-files-inside-a-jar-file, #10
226                if (!Files.isDirectory(path)) {
227                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("path is not a directory: " + path.toString());
228                }
229                
230                List<Path> pathList = new ArrayList<Path>();
231                Stream<Path> walk = null;
232                try {
233                        walk = Files.walk(path, 1);
234                } catch (IOException e) {
235                        e.printStackTrace();
236                }
237
238                for (Iterator<Path> it = walk.iterator(); it.hasNext();){
239                        Path p = it.next();
240                        if (Files.isRegularFile(p) && Files.isReadable(p)) {
241                                pathList.add(p);
242                        }
243                }
244                walk.close();
245                return pathList.toArray(new Path[0]);
246        }
247        
248}
